--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> Perhaps we don't mean the same thing by the term
> "sexual reproduction".  I was referring to the
> phenomenon of gender, whereby the population of one
> species is divided into two groups, and mating can
> only be with an individual from the other group. 
> Also, each individual carries a pair of homologous
> chromosomes, one of which came from the father and the
> other from the mother.  The phenotype depends on both
> chromosomes in a complicated way. (And of course there
> are multiple pairs of chromosomes in most species.)

It is a good idea to define terminology fairly precisely, since the 
GA literature borrows from biology, but there isn't always a nice 
conceptual fit.

I was referring to sexual reproduction as a mode of reproduction 
that requires two parents whose offspring are genetically composed 
of traits from both parents.

The most important distinction I'd make between a sexual model and 
an asexual one is that the first model employs both mutation and 
crossover, while the second uses only mutation as the primary means 
for traversing a given search space.

I wouldn't put the constraints of dimorphism or gender-distinct 
organs on the definition of sexual reproduction, and I'm not sure 
most biologists would either.  In fact, yeast and algae reproduce 
both asexually and sexually, do they not?  And not all sexually-
reproducing organisms do so under the conditions you outline above, 
such as polyploidy. 

> NEAT doesn't model any of that, or did I miss that in
> my reading?  

NEAT does model the production of offspring from two parents, 
comprising traits inherited from both.  Topology is dominant based 
on fitness, and crossover occurs in matching genes.  I think this 
model is much more accurately described as sexual than as asexual 
(which I would be more likely to ascribe to GAs in which offspring 
are cloned from the fittest, then simply mutated to some degree).  
Wouldn't you agree?

Derek
